title: New Study Shows Cannabis Boosts Memory in Older Mice
author: John Perritano
description: Researchers have shown that THC in marijuana alters the structure of the brains in older mice to be more like brains of younger mice. Could the same be true for humans?
cleaned_text: Can ingesting low doses of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), the psychotropic chemical in [marijuana](https://science.howstuffworks.com/marijuana.htm), improve the memory of the elderly? German and Israeli researchers believe so. In a [study](https://www.nature.com/articles/nm.4311.epdf) published in the May journal of Nature Medicine, scientists from the [University of Bonn](https://www.uni-bonn.de/the-university) and [The Hebrew University of Jerusalem](http://new.huji.ac.il/en) found that when older mice received low doses of THC, their memories improved. The discovery may give doctors a new tool to help boost cognitive development in older people, especially those with [dementia](https://health.howstuffworks.com/mental-health/dementia/delay-dementia.htm). Advertisement The findings are somewhat of a shocker, considering [studies](http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fpsyt.2013.00053/full#h1) have consistently shown that long-term marijuana use by adolescents can alter the structure of their brains, specifically those areas that deal with memory. In this latest research, however, scientists say the opposite is true, at least when it comes to elderly mice.
